I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  has  asked  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) to support the 
development of a multimodal passenger transport policy based on international best practice. 
During the fact-finding mission, ADB and the government reached an understanding on the 
impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference for consulting services for the TA.1 The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The increasing size of cities and growth of intercity travel have led to increases in the 
average length of passenger journeys in the PRC. Longer trips also mean that an increasing 
number of journeys will be multimodal, involving use of more than one mode to complete a 
single trip, and requiring transfers between modes. In passenger transportation, multimodal 
journeys are quite common and a multimodal transport hub (or transport interchange) is defined 
as a place where passengers change transport modes. This can be at train stations, rapid 
transit stations, bus stops, tram stops, airports, or anywhere that two or more of these modes 
come together. These transfer points play an important role in transportation, and can become a 
bottleneck if not adequately developed. Well-designed and integrated multimodal passenger 
transport hubs are therefore needed to reduce inefficiencies, reduce travel times, and increase 
traveler convenience.  
 
3.  A good passenger transport system is often built around a high-capacity rail system. 
Other  modes  such  as  buses,  taxis,  and  nonmotorized  vehicles  are  typically  used  when 
transporting passengers between a train station and their home or working place. Thus the 
interchange between trains and other modes is often inevitable in a well-functioning public 
transportation network. Short interchange times are consequently a very important factor in 
making public transportation a viable alternative for personal travel.  
 
4.  In the PRC, the high-speed rail network has been rapidly expanded. However, railway 
stations for the new lines are often located far from city centers, and poorly integrated with the 
city transport systems. Thus, while the high-speed rail network will facilitate faster intercity or 
suburban travel, the stations and surrounding areas must be efficiently linked to the existing city 
with  well-designed  multimodal  transport  infrastructure  and  high-quality  integrated  public 
transport services. This will ensure a reduction in transport costs, increase travel opportunities 
and regional accessibility to jobs and services, and promote economic development and poverty 
reduction.   
 
5.  A key challenge is how to assess the performance of multimodal passenger transport 
hubs. Presently the PRC has no technical standards or specifications to guide the development 
of high-quality multimodal hubs. The result has been urban transport systems with relatively 
inconvenient transfers, longer trip times, and higher transport costs than would be achieved with 
better coordinated planning and integrated multimodal transfer facilities. Simple, but important, 
variables are needed to assess the performance of hubs. For instance, “time of transfer” is a 
key variable that indicates the time needed to transfer across modes. A traveling passenger will 
usually not accept an excessively long waiting time at a mode change point and considerable 
delays during transfers may induce shifts to private vehicles. Hence terminal layouts can be

assessed using transfer times as a performance measure. This would ensure designs that 
facilitate passenger convenience by focusing on short walking distances and easily accessible 
waiting areas. Such performance measures are needed to guide the design and development of 
multimodal hubs. 
 
6.  In  the  PRC,  lack  of  institutional  coordination  is  another  barrier  to  developing  good 
multimodal  hubs.  The  planning,  implementation,  and  management  of  key  transport 
infrastructure and systems is typically carried out by agencies operating independently. For 
example, new railway stations are designed and built by the Ministry of Railways. Land is 
usually provided in a nearby but separate location for local or intercity bus companies to 
construct bus stations. The independent facilities are generally well designed and constructed, 
but often lack efficient physical connections between modes, have limited information and fare 
system integration, and tend to cluster distinct mode-specific hubs rather than combine them in 
single multimodal facilities. This results in poor service for passengers, unsafe and congested 
pedestrian  movements,  and  consumes  too  much  urban  land—inhibiting  land  development 
opportunities. 
 
7.  The main goals of multimodal transport hub design can be summarized as follows: 
 
(i)  Provide an efficient point of transfer between transport modes to streamline and 
optimize overall transport network functionality. In the absence of transit hubs, 
public transport tends to have less coverage and significant route overlaps and 
redundancy, leading to increasing road congestion and reducing the economic 
viability of public transport operations.  
(ii)  Provide  quality  service  for  passengers  to  make  public  transportation  an 
appealing option. Given the choice, many people would prefer a nonstop journey 
from  door-to-door  by  a  private  vehicle.  A  high-quality  hub,  providing  a 
comfortable and seamless transfer experience, is a vital ingredient for making 
public transport an attractive alternative to using private vehicles. This will reduce 
energy  consumption  and  greenhouse  gas  emissions,  and  provide  a  more 
sustainable economic basis for public transport operators.  
(iii)  Maximize  the  commercial  opportunity  within  the  hub  to  provide  additional 
revenue  sources  to  contribute  to  meeting  the  cost  of  hub  operation  and 
maintenance. The high-traffic flow is attractive to many types of commercial 
operators and, if properly designed and managed, can generate income without 
compromising operations or quality of service. 
(iv)  Integrate with the surrounding urban area to maximize the pedestrian catchment 
area and encourage transit-oriented development. 
 
8.  The TA focuses on enhancing the efficiency and appeal of public transport systems and 
multimodal integration; this fits well with ADB’s Sustainable Transport Initiative, which provides 
new directions to promote more environmentally and socially sustainable transport systems in 
line with Strategy 2020.2 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA will assist the government with the planning and implementation of multimodal 
passenger  hubs  in  urban  areas.  It  will  support  development  of  a  multimodal  passenger

Manila.

3
transportation policy by introducing and incorporating international best practices. The TA will 
develop  guidelines  and  recommendations  to  support  the  appraisal  and  development  of 
multimodal passenger hubs with the aim of providing fast and efficient transfers as well as 
comfortable and convenient facilities. It will examine issues of integrating land use in hub 
designs  and  the  potential  for  realizing  the  land  value  gains  and  commercial  spinoffs  for 
enhancing the financial viability of multimodal hub projects. The TA will focus on bringing 
together examples of best practice multimodal hubs from around the PRC and internationally, 
identifying key features of best-practice hubs, and determining their impact on system and 
financial performance. It will publish detailed guidelines on best practices for different types of 
hubs; and prepare plans for a scheme to provide incentives for cooperation among all modes 
and stakeholders. 
 
10.  The TA will specifically focus on hubs being developed around railway stations since 
such hubs represent the major area of opportunity and expansion in the PRC. The TA will 
explore the most efficient ways of achieving integration between modes such as bus, taxi, urban 
rail, intercity rail, and nonmotorized transport. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA will be improved efficiency and usability of multimodal hubs in the 
PRC.  The  outcome  is  that  policy  recommendations,  measures,  and  actions  for  integrated 
multimodal passenger transport hubs development are implemented. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will have three main outputs intended to support the development of multimodal 
hubs  in  the  PRC:  (i)  illustrated  multimodal  hub  development  guide,  (ii)  recommendations 
(including  indicators)  for  performance  assessment  of  multimodal  hubs,  and  (iii)  policy 
recommendations for improving interagency coordination. 
 
13.  Illustrated multimodal hub development guide. The TA will focus on bringing together 
examples of best practice multimodal hubs from around the PRC and internationally, identify 
key features and determine their impact on system performance, and publish detailed guidelines 
on best practices for different types of hubs.  
 
14.  The  illustrated  guide  will  be  published  as  a  knowledge  product  for  designing  and 
developing multimodal passenger transport hubs. It will be created in a web format version, 
which will be uploaded for ready reference. The book will (i) discuss key principles of multimodal 
hub design; (ii) explain potential design features, particularly in the context of passenger and 
vehicular flow diagrams; (iii) discuss and illustrate examples of integrated land use planning for 
such  hubs  based  on  successful  experiences  in  other  countries;  (iv)  provide  pictures, 
photographs,  design  concepts,  and  three-dimensional  views  to  explain  best  practice;  and  
(v) include illustrated examples based on reviews of existing designs of hubs that have been 
completed or are under construction. 
 
15.  Recommendations  (including  indicators)  for  performance  assessment  of 
multimodal  hubs. A key aspect of the study will be to conduct research on the financial 
measures, appraisal methodology, and performance specifications that can be used to assess 
the  proposed  multimodal  hub  projects.  Examples  include  (i)  design  standards  reflected  in 
performance  measures  of  multimodal  transfers  such  as  maximum  distances  or  maximum 
transfer times between modes; (ii) financial standards based on minimum–maximum ratios such

4   
as investment–time saved; (iii) service standards based on information system specifications, 
ticketing systems, and standards for signage and other services; and (iv) model for realizing 
land value gains and commercial spinoffs to enhance overall financial viability. The findings and 
recommendations will be published as a policy-oriented knowledge product. 
 
16.  The standards may be different depending on passenger demand projected for the hub, 
the number of modes to be integrated, and the size and type of facility. The TA will conduct 
research on key financial and performance measures and establish benchmarks based on best 
practice multimodal hubs from around the world for multimodal accessibility, efficiency, and 
financial sustainability. 
 
17.   Policy  recommendations  for  improving  interagency  coordination.  The  TA  will 
prepare  a  detailed  scheme  to  provide  incentives  for  cooperation  among  all  modes  and 
stakeholders.  The  TA  outputs  will  include  stakeholder  workshops  to  disseminate  the  best 
practices in multimodal hub design, promote consensus in strategies for improving interagency 
coordination, and formulate a proposed implementation strategy that identifies new projects that 
could apply the recommendations. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The government has requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).  
The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  suitably  furnished  office 
accommodation with utilities; telecommunications access; materials, maps, data and documents 
required  by  the  TA;  counterpart  professional  staff,  and  support  staff;  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The Ministry of Transport (MOT) will be the executing agency for the TA. It will be 
responsible  for  guiding  and  supervising  the  TA  activities  and  coordinating  with  relevant 
government agencies and organizations, including provincial and local governments. MOT is 
supporting the implementation of pilot and demonstration multimodal hub projects in a number 
of  provinces.  Currently,  plans  are  in  place  to  build  more  than  100  passenger-transport 
multimodal hubs in the PRC. MOT needs effective models of support, and technical guidelines 
and  standards  to  guide  the  implementation  of  multimodal  passenger  hubs  in  urban  areas 
nationwide. The support for multimodal hubs represents an opportunity to develop a new area 
for ADB-financed investment in urban transport in the PRC in line with the direction of ADB’s 
Sustainable Transport Initiative. 
 
20.  The TA will require about 18 person-months of national and about 7 person-months of 
international consulting services to carry out the terms of reference (Appendix 3). ADB will 
engage a team of national consultants through a consulting firm, in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) on the basis of the 
quality of the proposal (90%) and the cost of services to be provided (10%), using simplified 
technical proposal procedures. The 90:10 weighting is appropriate because (i) the TA is an 
advanced assignment that requires a high degree of expertise in multimodal hub designs, and  
(ii) the TA is likely to have a significant impact on future development of multimodal hubs in the 
PRC.

5
21.  ADB will engage individual international consultants in accordance with the Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants. Individual consultants are needed, as the TA is an advanced 
assignment that requires specialized expertise in integrated urban transport hub designs and 
institutional coordination. These are new themes, even within developed countries, and the 
required skill sets are unlikely to be readily available through firms. The individuals may be from 
academia in order to have a suitable background to develop the best practice guide that collates 
varied experiences in multiple countries. 
 
22.  Disbursement will be undertaken in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented from 15 February 
2012 to 15 March 2013. 
 
23.  The consultants will submit inception, interim, draft final, and other reports as applicable. 
They will hold regular workshops to present findings and recommendations and solicit feedback 
from key stakeholders. The Ministry of Railways and other relevant ministries and agencies will 
be closely consulted and involved during TA implementation and in the review of the TA outputs. 
They will be invited to participate in the review workshops and discussions pertaining to the TA. 
ADB missions will monitor TA progress and performance. The consultants are expected to 
prepare  and  disseminate  working  papers  describing  key  findings,  recommendations,  and 
lessons from TA implementation. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Developing  Multimodal  Passenger 
Transport Hubs, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  consultants  will  perform  their  tasks  in  close  consultation  with  the  Ministry  of 
Transport (MOT), other national government agencies, and local governments to ensure full 
acceptance of the outcome of the technical assistance (TA). The TA will require 25 person-
months of consulting services (7 person-months international and 18 person-months national) 
over 13 months. The following types of specialists will be recruited:  
 
(i)  integrated urban transport planning specialist (3 person-months international, 5 
person-months national), 
(ii)  architect (2.5 person-months international, 4 person-months national), 
(iii)  financial specialist (1.5 person-months international, 3 person-months national), 
(iv)  civil engineer (3 person-months national), and 
(v)  institutional coordination specialist (3 person-months national). 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
2.  The objective of the TA is to guide the development and construction of multimodal 
passenger  hubs  that  will  provide  fast  and  efficient  transfers,  comfortable  and  convenient 
facilities, integrated systems, and high-quality designs. The expected outputs and tasks are 
summarized below: 
 
(i)  Output  1:    Illustrated  multimodal  hub  development  guide  published. 
Research  examples  of  best  practice  and  lessons  from  multimodal  hubs 
developed in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and internationally, identify 
key features and determine their impact on system performance, and publish 
detailed guidelines on best practices for different types of hubs. 
(ii)  Output  2:  Recommendations  (including  indicators)  for  performance 
assessment completed. Conduct research on key financial and performance 
measures and establish benchmarks based on best practice multimodal hubs 
from  around  the  world  for  multimodal  accessibility,  efficiency,  and  financial 
viability.  Identify  the  key  variables  and  indicators  for  assessing  the  financial 
viability  of  the  project  and  develop  a  framework  for  assessing  the  same. 
Recommend options for enhancing the financial viability of multimodal hubs. 
Publish as a policy-oriented knowledge brief. 
(iii)  Output 3: Policy recommendations for improving interagency coordination 
developed.  Prepare  a  scheme  linked  to  the  subsidy  program  and  propose 
policies to provide incentives for cooperation among all modes and stakeholders. 
 
B.  Specific Tasks 
 
1.  Integrated  Urban  Transport  Planning  Specialist  (3  person-months 
international and 5 person-months national)  
 
3.  The integrated urban transport specialists (national and international) will contribute to all 
the tasks and act as the team leader (national) and deputy team leader (international). The team 
leader and deputy team leader will be responsible for ensuring close coordination between the 
national and international consultants. 
 
4.  The international consultant should have extensive knowledge and experience (at least 
10 years) with urban planning, and policy development and reform in one or more developed

10  Appendix 3 
countries, and should have extensive experience formulating integrated multimodal transport 
sector strategies and designing multimodal passenger transport hubs. The national integrated 
urban transport specialist will act as the team leader. In addition to overseeing the work of the 
national consultants, the specialist will act as the liaison person with the government. The team 
leader will have overall responsibility for the effective and timely implementation of the TA. The 
national consultant should have extensive knowledge and experience (at least 7 years) with 
urban planning, and development of multimodal transport hubs. 
 
5.  The consultants’ work will include the following: 
 
(i)  Conduct research on the technical standards and specifications of hub designs to 
be promoted as part of the multimodal hub program. 
(ii)  Provide expert advice on lessons from international experience in developing 
integrated multimodal hubs. 
(iii)  Develop  a  guidance  methodology  for  forecasting  traffic  demands  for  each 
transport  mode  and  determining  the  transfer  rate  needed  between  different 
modes for providing guidance on the design of hubs. 
(iv)  Assess the training needs of key government officials and plan an international 
training program to visit examples of best practice multimodal hubs. 
(v)  Provide recommendations on integrated land use planning for such hubs and the 
potential for realizing the land value gains for enhancing the financial viability of 
multimodal hub projects based on successful experiences in other countries. 
(vi)  Develop design standards that reflect best practices in terms of the measurable 
performance of multimodal transfers, such as maximum distances or transfer 
times between modes for different types of multimodal hubs. 
(vii)  Recommend standards to be adopted for improved services at these hubs such 
as information system specifications; ticketing, signage, and universal designs to 
facilitate the needs of the elderly, disabled, and women. 
 
6.  In addition, the team leader will be responsible for: 
 
(i)  Fostering close coordination between international and national consultants and 
coordinating with the executing agency, other related government agencies, the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), and other international organizations. 
(ii)  Planning and leading the workshops and seminar.  
(iii)  Arranging pictures and photographs of the hubs visited during the international 
trip and from other sources for the illustrated guide. 
(iv)  Ensuring the timeliness and high quality of the inception, interim, and final reports 
and assuming primary responsibility for developing and implementing knowledge 
products and services to disseminate the study findings and policy proposals to 
senior decision-makers. 
 
2.  Architect (2.5 person-months international and 4 person-months national)  
 
7.  The  architects  should  have  extensive  knowledge  and  experience  with  designing 
multimodal passenger hubs. They will be responsible for delivering tasks 1 and 2. Work will 
include the following: 
(i)  Develop  a  set  of  key  standards  and  multimodal  hub  design  principles  that 
passenger hubs should aspire to meet to promote (a) passenger convenience, 
(b) user comfort, (c) safety, and (d) aesthetic quality.

(ii)  Develop conceptual designs and illustrations of best practice multimodal hubs 
using a range of visual aids. 
(iii)  Provide  detailed  inputs  for  the  illustrated  guidebook,  including  pictures, 
photographs, and schematics that demonstrate best practices in multimodal hub 
designs. 
(iv)  Review the plans of at least two multimodal hubs under development and give 
suggestions to improve them using best practice examples. 
(v)  Conduct  research  on  key  performance  measures  and  establish  benchmarks 
based on best practice multimodal hubs from around the world for multimodal 
accessibility and efficiency. 
(vi)  Assist in developing design standards that reflect best practices in terms of the 
measurable performance of multimodal transfers, such as maximum distances or 
transfer times between modes for different types of multimodal hubs. 
 
3.  Financial  Specialist  (1.5  person-months  international  and  3  person-months 
national) 
 
8.  The financial specialists should have experience carrying out financial appraisal and 
feasibility  assessments  of  multimodal  passenger  hubs  and  have  been  involved  in  the 
assessment of at least two passenger multimodal hubs. They will be responsible for delivering 
task 2. Their work will include the following: 
(i)  Identify  and  suggest  a  quantification  method  for  the  main  variables  that 
determine the costs and benefits of multimodal hubs. 
(ii)  Develop  a  framework  for  carrying  out  financial  and  economic  analysis  of 
multimodal hub projects. 
(iii)  Recommend  financial  measures  and  minimum–maximum  ratios  such  as 
investment–time saved that could be used for assessing projects. 
(iv)  Recommend options for accessing additional revenue streams and enhancing 
the financial viability of such projects. 
(v)  Research examples of good business models including land value capture and 
give recommendations applicable to the PRC. 
 
4.  Civil Engineer (3 person-months national) 
 
9.  The  civil  engineer  should  have  experience  with  designing  and  costing  multimodal 
passenger  hubs  and  have  been  involved  in  the  design  and  development  of  at  least 
two passenger multimodal hubs. The consultant will be responsible for delivering tasks 1 and 2. 
Work will include to the following: 
 
(i)  Assist in developing conceptual designs of multimodal hubs computed aided 
design packages. 
(ii)  Provide engineering review of constructability and design feasibility, and prepare 
indicative cost estimates of multimodal hub designs and concept plans. 
(iii)  Assist  in  preparing  a  reference  book  with  pictures  that  demonstrate  best 
practices in multimodal hub designs. 
(iv)  Review the plans of at least two multimodal hubs under development and give 
suggestions using best practice examples. 
(v)  Conduct  research  on  key  performance  measures  and  establish  benchmarks 
based on best practice multimodal hubs from around the world for multimodal 
accessibility and efficiency.

12  Appendix 3 
(vi)  Assist in developing design and technical standards that reflect best practices in 
terms of the measurable performance of multimodal transfers, such as maximum 
distances  or  transfer  times  between  modes  for  different  types  of multimodal 
hubs. 
 
5.  Institutional Coordination Specialist (3 person-months national) 
 
10.  The  institutional  coordination  specialist  should  have  extensive  knowledge  and 
experience  of  institutions  and  policy,  including  in-depth  appreciation  of  the  role  and 
responsibility of MOT and other key PRC ministries, and provincial and local governments 
involved in developing, managing, and operating various transport modes. The consultant will 
be responsible for delivering task 3. Tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Identify and liaise with key stakeholders and agencies including, as appropriate, 
Ministry of Construction, Ministry of Railways, MOT, National Development and 
Reform  Commission,  urban  public  transport  operators,  local  and  regional 
planners and design institutes, taxi federations and companies, long distance bus 
operators, ferry operators, and any other transport user representatives. 
(ii)  Plan  and  convene  stakeholder  consultations  and/or  focus  groups,  including 
transport system user representatives, to solicit ideas and possible strategies for 
promoting interagency and intermodal cooperation. 
(iii)  Prepare a detailed scheme linked to the subsidy program and propose policies to 
provide incentives for cooperation among all modes and stakeholders. 
(iv)  Develop an appropriate legal and regulatory decree (such as in the form of a 
state decree and ministerial orders) that the central government can issue to 
ensure better institutional coordination. 
 
C.  Reporting and Workshops 
 
11.  The consultants will submit the following reports:  
 
(i)  an  inception  report,  3  weeks  after  commencement  of  services,  detailing  the 
consultant team’s understanding of the issues to be addressed in the TA; the 
approach, methodology, and information required to complete the TA; and the 
initial thinking of the consultant team on the recommended policy directions;  
(ii)  a draft illustrated guide on best practices and an interim report including initial 
findings, financial and performance indicators, and draft recommendations for 
providing incentives for best practices and improving institutional coordination 
after 24 weeks;  
(iii)  a  draft  final  illustrated  guide  and  a  draft  final  report  (knowledge  product) 
containing  policy  recommendations  after  36  weeks  (including  key  findings, 
conclusions,  benchmarking  indicators,  and  institutional  coordination  scheme); 
and  
(iv)  a final version of the illustrated guide and report (knowledge product) 4 weeks 
after receipt of review comments from ADB and MOT.  
 
12.  MOT requires five copies of each report in English and Chinese, the Ministry of Finance 
(TA Division) needs two copies of each report in English and Chinese, and ADB requires five 
copies of each report in English and Chinese. The consultants will report on progress and key 
findings. The team leader and the deputy team leader will edit the reports and illustrated guide 
for publication. All reports will be submitted in hard and soft copy.

Appendix 3  13 
 
13.  The  consultants  will  organize  an  inception  meeting  and  two  workshops,  which  will 
include high-level consultation with key policy makers and other sector stakeholders.  
(i)  The inception meeting will review the inception report and provide guidance to 
the consultants for implementing the various tasks specified under the terms of 
reference.  
(ii)  The first workshop will be conducted after the international training tour, discuss 
the outcomes and lessons from the training tour, and analyze the best practice 
examples seen during the tour. It will discuss findings regarding the assessment 
of multimodal hubs and possible financial and performance measures and the 
process of evaluating the financial viability and performance of multimodal hubs. 
(iii)  The third workshop will be used to launch the illustrated guide and detailed report 
(knowledge  product)  on  appraising  multimodal  hubs.  It  will  discuss  issues 
pertaining to achieving better institutional coordination.
